content: Mix together roughly equal parts of baking soda and water. In a small cup, mix ½ teaspoon (3 g) of baking soda with enough water to form a paste, or ¼ to ½ teaspoon (1 ¼ to 2 ½ mL). A paste of 1 to 2 parts of baking soda mixed with 1 part of water is easier to apply and more effective than baking soda alone. [1] Avoid making a paste with baking soda and lemon, strawberry, or any other fruit juice. Fruit juices are acidic and could erode your teeth's enamel, especially when combined with baking soda or other abrasive products. [2] Brush your teeth with the baking soda paste for 1 to 2 minutes. Dip a soft-bristled brush into the paste, and gently scrub your teeth using circular motions. Brush all around instead of scrubbing 1 spot for the entire 2 minutes. Be sure not to brush hard or you might hurt your teeth. [3] Alternatively, use your fingertips to gently rub your teeth with the paste. Rub in soft circles, and don’t use too much force. If you have receding gums, avoid brushing the base of your teeth and around your gum line with baking soda. The substance that covers your teeth below the gums is softer than enamel and prone to damage. [4] Rinse out your mouth when you’re finished brushing. After brushing for 2 minutes, spit out the baking soda and rinse your mouth with water or mouthwash. Give your toothbrush a thorough rinse as well. Note that you shouldn’t rinse after brushing with a fluoride toothpaste, as rinsing reduces fluoride’s beneficial effects. For this reason, don’t brush or rinse with baking soda right after brushing with regular toothpaste. If you really need to rinse away visible residue after using regular toothpaste, use as little water as possible. [5] Repeat every other day for up to 2 weeks. At most, brush your teeth with baking soda paste every other day for 1 to 2 weeks. Then cut back to doing it just once or twice a week. Since it’s abrasive, using baking soda more frequently may damage your teeth. [6] Keep in mind that brushing your teeth with baking soda should not replace brushing your teeth with regular toothpaste. Brushing twice a day with a fluoride toothpaste, flossing daily, and regular dental checkups are the best ways to keep your teeth healthy. Before brushing with baking soda, check with your dentist to see if your teeth are healthy enough for this method. Your teeth may be sensitive to abrasion, and baking soda may cause irreversible dental erosion. Mix 2 parts of baking soda with 1 part of 1% to 3% hydrogen peroxide. Hydrogen peroxide may whiten teeth, but you need to use it with caution. To try this method, mix 2 parts of baking with 1 part of 1% to 3% hydrogen peroxide to form a paste. Brush your teeth with the mixture for 1 to 2 minutes, then rinse with water. [7] Make sure you use hydrogen peroxide with a concentration of 3% or less. Brush with hydrogen peroxide and baking soda once a week at most. Stop brushing and rinse your mouth with cool water if you feel a burning sensation. Don’t use this method if you have receding or sensitive gums, as hydrogen peroxide can cause irritation and damage exposed roots. [8] Brush your teeth with a mix of baking soda and fluoride toothpaste. Squeeze your regular toothpaste onto your toothbrush, then sprinkle a pinch of baking soda on top. Brush your teeth as you normally would for 2 minutes with soft, circular motions. Then spit and, if you need to rinse away white residue, swish your mouth with a little water. [10] As with a baking soda and water paste, brush with baking soda and toothpaste in moderation. Try it every other day for 1 to 2 weeks at first, then brush with baking soda once or twice a week at most. You can also purchase a toothpaste that already contains baking soda. In the United States, look for a product that carries the ADA (American Dental Association) Seal of Acceptance, and use it as directed. [11] If you have sensitive teeth or dental erosion, avoid using toothpastes that contain baking soda or are branded as whitening products. [12] Gargle with a baking soda and water rinse. Combine 1 teaspoon (6 g) of baking soda and 1 cup (240 mL) of water in a glass, then stir the mixture until the baking soda is evenly distributed. Take a sip, gargle for about 30 seconds, then spit out the mixture. Repeat the steps until you’ve finished the entire glass. [13] The baking soda rinse won't erode your teeth, so it's safe to gargle with it daily. Gargling with a baking soda rinse whitens your teeth indirectly. Baking soda neutralizes acids, so it helps fight dental erosion caused by acidic foods and beverages. It can also help fight bacteria that cause decay and promote good bacteria that create a protective layer on your teeth. [14]

<div id="bodycontents">
<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda">How to Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Cristian Macau, DDS</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Brushing_with_a_Baking_Soda_Paste_sub" id="">Brushing with a Baking Soda Paste</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Trying_Alternative_Methods_sub" id="">Trying Alternative Methods</a>
<a class="" href="#" id="summary_toc">Article Summary</a>
<a class="" href="#Questions_and_Answers_sub" id="qa_toc">Questions & Answers</a>

<a class="toc_ref" href="#references" id="">References</a>
</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=cristianmacau%2Cdds#cristianmacau%2Cdds">Cristian Macau, DDS</a>. Dr. Macau is an oral surgeon, periodontist, and aesthetician at Favero Dental Clinic in London. He received his DDS from Carol Davila University of Medicine in 2015.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">18 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Having white teeth can be a major confidence boost. Fortunately, you may not need to spend lots of money on whitening kits or professional treatments. Brushing or rinsing with baking soda could help whiten your teeth, but be aware you should use it carefully. To prevent dental erosion, brush with baking soda in moderation and avoid using too much force. Bear in mind discoloration may point to dental issues, so try to see a dentist if you haven't had a checkup in a while.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Brushing_with_a_Baking_Soda_Paste_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Brushing_with_a_Baking_Soda_Paste">Brushing with a Baking Soda Paste</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-1-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1763" href="#/Image:Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-1-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid1763-v4-728px-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-1-Version-4.jpg" height="410" id="img_a35b793623" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a35b793623')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="410" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid1763-v4-728px-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-1-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Mix together roughly equal parts of baking soda and water.</b> In a small cup, mix ½ teaspoon (3 g) of baking soda with enough water to form a paste, or ¼ to ½ teaspoon (1 ¼ to 2 ½ mL). A paste of 1 to 2 parts of baking soda mixed with 1 part of water is easier to apply and more effective than baking soda alone.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Avoid making a paste with baking soda and lemon, strawberry, or any other fruit juice. Fruit juices are acidic and could erode your teeth's enamel, especially when combined with baking soda or other abrasive products.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="green_box expert green_tip">
<div class="green_box_person expert">
<div class="green_box_person_circle"><img alt="Cristian Macau, DDS" src="/images/thumb/8/84/Cristian-Macau.jpg/-crop-200-200-200px-Cristian-Macau.jpg"/></div>
<div class="green_box_expert_label">EXPERT ADVICE</div>
</div>
<div class="green_box_content">
<p><b>Cristian Macau, D.D.S, a Dentist, advises:</b> "You shouldn't whiten your teeth with baking soda more than once a day and no longer than 2 weeks in a row. Stop the procedure for 1 week and repeat if necessary."</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/74/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-2-Version-5.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/1/10/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-2-Version-5.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-2-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-2-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/9/99/Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 2 Version 5.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-ac218e284e" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Brush-Your-Teeth" title="Brush Your Teeth">Brush</a> your teeth with the baking soda paste for 1 to 2 minutes.</b> Dip a soft-bristled brush into the paste, and gently scrub your teeth using circular motions. Brush all around instead of scrubbing 1 spot for the entire 2 minutes. Be sure not to brush hard or you might hurt your teeth.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-ac218e284e'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>Alternatively, use your fingertips to gently rub your teeth with the paste. Rub in soft circles, and don’t use too much force.</li>
<li>If you have receding gums, avoid brushing the base of your teeth and around your gum line with baking soda. The substance that covers your teeth below the gums is softer than enamel and prone to damage.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/2/2d/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-3-Version-5.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/1/18/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-3-Version-5.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-3-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-3-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/9/99/Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 3 Version 5.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-4cbdcfea94" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Rinse out your mouth when you’re finished brushing.</b> After brushing for 2 minutes, spit out the baking soda and rinse your mouth with water or mouthwash. Give your toothbrush a thorough rinse as well.<script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-4cbdcfea94'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>Note that you shouldn’t rinse after brushing with a fluoride toothpaste, as rinsing reduces fluoride’s beneficial effects. For this reason, don’t brush or rinse with baking soda right after brushing with regular toothpaste. If you really need to rinse away visible residue after using regular toothpaste, use as little water as possible.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/9/95/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-4-Version-5.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/5/57/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-4-Version-5.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-4-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-4-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/a/ac/Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 4 Version 5.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-730ad566ac" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Repeat every other day for up to 2 weeks.</b> At most, brush your teeth with baking soda paste every other day for 1 to 2 weeks. Then cut back to doing it just once or twice a week. Since it’s abrasive, using baking soda more frequently may damage your teeth.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-730ad566ac'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>Keep in mind that brushing your teeth with baking soda should not replace brushing your teeth with regular toothpaste. Brushing twice a day with a fluoride toothpaste, flossing daily, and regular dental checkups are the best ways to keep your teeth healthy.</li>
<li>Before brushing with baking soda, check with your dentist to see if your teeth are healthy enough for this method. Your teeth may be sensitive to abrasion, and baking soda may cause irreversible dental erosion.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Trying_Alternative_Methods_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Trying_Alternative_Methods">Trying Alternative Methods</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/cc/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-5-Version-5.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/1/13/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-5-Version-5.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-5-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-5-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/1/1d/Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 5 Version 5.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-a372b27386" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Mix 2 parts of baking soda with 1 part of 1% to 3% hydrogen peroxide.</b> <a href="/Whiten-Teeth-With-Hydrogen-Peroxide" title="Whiten Teeth With Hydrogen Peroxide">Hydrogen peroxide</a> may whiten teeth, but you need to use it with caution. To try this method, mix 2 parts of baking with 1 part of 1% to 3% hydrogen peroxide to form a paste. Brush your teeth with the mixture for 1 to 2 minutes, then rinse with water.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-a372b27386'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>Make sure you use hydrogen peroxide with a concentration of 3% or less. Brush with hydrogen peroxide and baking soda once a week at most.</li>
<li>Stop brushing and rinse your mouth with cool water if you feel a burning sensation. Don’t use this method if you have receding or sensitive gums, as hydrogen peroxide can cause irritation and damage exposed roots.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="green_box green_tip">
<p><b>Safety tip:</b> It's important to rinse out your mouth thoroughly after using hydrogen peroxide. Even diluted solutions can cause vomiting and stomach upset if ingested. Additionally, any residue left behind could bleach your teeth and lead to uneven whitening.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup></p>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player">
<div class="video-container content-fill"><video class="m-video content-fill" controlslist="nodownload" data-controls="1" data-giffirstsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/5/56/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-7-Version-5.360p.first.gif" data-gifsrc="https://www.wikihow.com/images/3/30/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-7-Version-5.360p.gif" data-poster="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-7-Version-4.jpg/550px-nowatermark-Whiten-Teeth-With-Baking-Soda-Step-7-Version-4.jpg" data-src="/5/5e/Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda Step 7 Version 5.360p.mp4" data-watermark="1" id="mvid-3bbf055947" loop="" muted="" playsinline="" webkit-playsinline=""></video></div>
<div class="m-video-controls"><div class="m-video-play-old"></div></div>
<div class="m-video-wm" data-wm-title-text="to Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda"><img class="m-video-wm-img" src="/skins/WikiHow/images/WH_logo.svg"/></div>
</div></div></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Brush your teeth with a mix of baking soda and fluoride toothpaste.</b> Squeeze your regular toothpaste onto your toothbrush, then sprinkle a pinch of baking soda on top. Brush your teeth as you normally would for 2 minutes with soft, circular motions. Then spit and, if you need to rinse away white residue, swish your mouth with a little water.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup><script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-3bbf055947'));
//]]>
</script>
<ul>
<li>As with a baking soda and water paste, brush with baking soda and toothpaste in moderation. Try it every other day for 1 to 2 weeks at first, then brush with baking soda once or twice a week at most.</li>
<li>You can also purchase a toothpaste that already contains baking soda. In the United States, look for a product that carries the ADA (American Dental Association) Seal of Acceptance, and use it as directed.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>If you have sensitive teeth or dental erosion, avoid using toothpastes that contain baking soda or are branded as whitening products.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Whiten-Teeth-with-Natural-Methods-Step-17-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1763" href="#/Image:Whiten-Teeth-with-Natural-Methods-Step-17-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Whiten Teeth with Natural Methods Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/50/Whiten-Teeth-with-Natural-Methods-Step-17-Version-4.jpg/aid1763-v4-728px-Whiten-Teeth-with-Natural-Methods-Step-17-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_3e39f8c081" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3e39f8c081')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Whiten Teeth with Natural Methods Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/50/Whiten-Teeth-with-Natural-Methods-Step-17-Version-4.jpg/aid1763-v4-728px-Whiten-Teeth-with-Natural-Methods-Step-17-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Gargle with a baking soda and water rinse.</b> Combine 1 teaspoon (6 g) of baking soda and 1 cup (240 mL) of water in a glass, then stir the mixture until the baking soda is evenly distributed. Take a sip, gargle for about 30 seconds, then spit out the mixture. Repeat the steps until you’ve finished the entire glass.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>The baking soda rinse won't erode your teeth, so it's safe to gargle with it daily.</li>
<li>Gargling with a baking soda rinse whitens your teeth indirectly. Baking soda neutralizes acids, so it helps fight dental erosion caused by acidic foods and beverages. It can also help fight bacteria that cause decay and promote good bacteria that create a protective layer on your teeth.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="1763" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="110174" data-caid="111047" data-cqid="110191" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="308388" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105127" data-votes_down="35" data-votes_up="157">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What if it doesn't work? Is there any other alternative?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=cristianmacau%2Cdds#cristianmacau%2Cdds" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/8/84/Cristian-Macau.jpg/-crop-200-200-200px-Cristian-Macau.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=cristianmacau%2Cdds#cristianmacau%2Cdds" target="_blank">Cristian Macau, DDS</a><br/>
	Doctor of Dental Surgery
</div>
Dr. Macau is an oral surgeon, periodontist, and aesthetician at Favero Dental Clinic in London. He received his DDS from Carol Davila University of Medicine in 2015.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=cristianmacau%2Cdds#cristianmacau%2Cdds" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/8/84/Cristian-Macau.jpg/-crop-200-200-200px-Cristian-Macau.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">

</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Doctor of Dental Surgery</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">If it doesn’t work at all (which is less likely), you will need a professional whitening treatment performed in a dental office under the guidance of an experienced dentist. Ask your dentist to do a tailored whitening, which consists of applying the gel on areas where whitening has not been complete.</div>

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="52994" data-caid="53867" data-cqid="53011" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="319384" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="33" data-votes_up="198">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Is baking soda harmful to the gums?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Only if you brush too hard with it. Be gentle and you won't have a problem. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>33</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>198</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="50953" data-caid="51826" data-cqid="50970" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="151462" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="27" data-votes_up="166">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can I use baking soda only?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Adding water to the baking soda makes it much easier to brush with. Using it alone is messy and more difficult to control. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>27</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>166</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="17766" data-caid="18638" data-cqid="17782" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="38951" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="63" data-votes_up="263">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Is baking soda harmful for enamel and teeth?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">It is abrasive by nature. If you leave the baking soda on for longer than a minute or two, it will start to erode the enamel. Also, if you are using baking soda to brush your teeth, only do it every other day for a minute or two, no longer.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>63</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>263</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="86545" data-caid="87418" data-cqid="86562" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="694441" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="17" data-votes_up="80">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can I brush my teeth after or does the method already replace brushing it?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You need to brush your teeth after using baking soda so your teeth do not erode.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>

</div>

</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="39715" data-caid="40588" data-cqid="39732" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="74970" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="43" data-votes_up="163">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Why does it taste like salt when I brush with baking soda?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Salt and baking soda both contain sodium so they taste similar.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

</div>

<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>163</span></a>
</div>
</div>

</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="18225" data-caid="19097" data-cqid="18241" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="250549" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="73" data-votes_up="254">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can I use baking powder instead of baking soda?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">

<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">No. It won't be effective.</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="16670" data-caid="17541" data-cqid="16685" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="165405" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="45" data-votes_up="164">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can baking soda damage your teeth?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">As noted in the Warnings accompanying this article, baking soda can cause corrosive damage when used excessively, and can damage gums if scrubbed too furiously with a toothbrush. Take your time, be gentle and don't do it more than every other day for a week. Let your teeth have a break. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>45</span></a>

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="55853" data-caid="56726" data-cqid="55870" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="411990" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="13">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Does it damage your teeth if you use it once a week?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">No damage should occur if you use it once a week. When you use it multiple times a week over an extended period of time is when the enamel on your teeth will be affected. Once or twice a week for two weeks should give a noticeably whiter smile. After about two weeks, once a week or so should be enough to maintain your pearly whites.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>

</div>

</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="39749" data-caid="40622" data-cqid="39766" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="73722" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="9" data-votes_up="32">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What if I wear braces?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Do not use this method if you have braces. The baking soda might erode the orthodontic glue, and you'd have to get them re-applied. Even if that problem didn't occur, the baking soda cannot clean the area under your brackets; when your braces are removed, the area will be darker than the rest of your teeth. </div>

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Avoid brushing your gums with baking soda or hydrogen peroxide.</li>
<li>Don't brush a single area of your mouth for too long. Divide 1 to 1 ½ minutes evenly among your top teeth, then brush your bottom teeth for a total of 1 to 1 ½ minutes.</li>
<li>Remember not to brush with a mix baking soda and lemon juice or other acidic substances.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>See a dentist if you’re concerned about whitening your teeth. Stains or discoloration may be signs of problems that require professional dental care.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Don’t brush your teeth with baking soda or abrasive toothpastes if you have sensitive teeth, which may indicate dental erosion. Brushing with abrasive products will just make matters worse.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Avoid brushing with baking soda or hydrogen peroxide if you have braces or a permanent retainer.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>To prevent uneven coloration or damage to your dental work, don’t use hydrogen peroxide or at-home bleaching kits if you have crowns, caps, or veneers.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>To whiten your teeth with baking soda, start by mixing equal parts baking soda and water. Then, brush your teeth with the baking soda paste for 2 minutes using gentle circular motions. When you're finished, rinse your mouth out with water. Repeat the process every other day for up to 2 weeks for the biggest impact on your smile. <span id="summary_last_sentence">For more advice from our Dental co-author, like how to whiten your teeth with hydrogen peroxide, scroll down!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Brushing with a Baking Soda Paste",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Mix together roughly equal parts of baking soda and water. In a small cup, mix \u00bd teaspoon (3 g) of baking soda with enough water to form a paste, or \u00bc to \u00bd teaspoon (1 \u00bc to 2 \u00bd mL). A paste of 1 to 2 parts of baking soda mixed with 1 part of water is easier to apply and more effective than baking soda alone.[1]\nAvoid making a paste with baking soda and lemon, strawberry, or any other fruit juice. Fruit juices are acidic and could erode your teeth's enamel, especially when combined with baking soda or other abrasive products.[2]\n\n\nEXPERT ADVICE\n\n\nCristian Macau, D.D.S, a Dentist, advises: \"You shouldn't whiten your teeth with baking soda more than once a day and no longer than 2 weeks in a row. Stop the procedure for 1 week and repeat if necessary.\""
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,

title: How to Whiten Teeth With Baking Soda
content_html:
Mix together roughly equal parts of baking soda and water. In a small cup, mix ½ teaspoon (3 g) of baking soda with enough water to form a paste, or ¼ to ½ teaspoon (1 ¼ to 2 ½ mL). A paste of 1 to 2 parts of baking soda mixed with 1 part of water is easier to apply and more effective than baking soda alone.[1]
  • Avoid making a paste with baking soda and lemon, strawberry, or any other fruit juice. Fruit juices are acidic and could erode your teeth's enamel, especially when combined with baking soda or other abrasive products.[2]
Brush your teeth with the baking soda paste for 1 to 2 minutes. Dip a soft-bristled brush into the paste, and gently scrub your teeth using circular motions. Brush all around instead of scrubbing 1 spot for the entire 2 minutes. Be sure not to brush hard or you might hurt your teeth.[3]
  • Alternatively, use your fingertips to gently rub your teeth with the paste. Rub in soft circles, and don’t use too much force.
  • If you have receding gums, avoid brushing the base of your teeth and around your gum line with baking soda. The substance that covers your teeth below the gums is softer than enamel and prone to damage.[4]
Rinse out your mouth when you’re finished brushing. After brushing for 2 minutes, spit out the baking soda and rinse your mouth with water or mouthwash. Give your toothbrush a thorough rinse as well.
  • Note that you shouldn’t rinse after brushing with a fluoride toothpaste, as rinsing reduces fluoride’s beneficial effects. For this reason, don’t brush or rinse with baking soda right after brushing with regular toothpaste. If you really need to rinse away visible residue after using regular toothpaste, use as little water as possible.[5]
Repeat every other day for up to 2 weeks. At most, brush your teeth with baking soda paste every other day for 1 to 2 weeks. Then cut back to doing it just once or twice a week. Since it’s abrasive, using baking soda more frequently may damage your teeth.[6]
  • Keep in mind that brushing your teeth with baking soda should not replace brushing your teeth with regular toothpaste. Brushing twice a day with a fluoride toothpaste, flossing daily, and regular dental checkups are the best ways to keep your teeth healthy.
  • Before brushing with baking soda, check with your dentist to see if your teeth are healthy enough for this method. Your teeth may be sensitive to abrasion, and baking soda may cause irreversible dental erosion.
Mix 2 parts of baking soda with 1 part of 1% to 3% hydrogen peroxide. Hydrogen peroxide may whiten teeth, but you need to use it with caution. To try this method, mix 2 parts of baking with 1 part of 1% to 3% hydrogen peroxide to form a paste. Brush your teeth with the mixture for 1 to 2 minutes, then rinse with water.[7]
  • Make sure you use hydrogen peroxide with a concentration of 3% or less. Brush with hydrogen peroxide and baking soda once a week at most.
  • Stop brushing and rinse your mouth with cool water if you feel a burning sensation. Don’t use this method if you have receding or sensitive gums, as hydrogen peroxide can cause irritation and damage exposed roots.[8]
Brush your teeth with a mix of baking soda and fluoride toothpaste. Squeeze your regular toothpaste onto your toothbrush, then sprinkle a pinch of baking soda on top. Brush your teeth as you normally would for 2 minutes with soft, circular motions. Then spit and, if you need to rinse away white residue, swish your mouth with a little water.[10]
  • As with a baking soda and water paste, brush with baking soda and toothpaste in moderation. Try it every other day for 1 to 2 weeks at first, then brush with baking soda once or twice a week at most.
  • You can also purchase a toothpaste that already contains baking soda. In the United States, look for a product that carries the ADA (American Dental Association) Seal of Acceptance, and use it as directed.[11]
  • If you have sensitive teeth or dental erosion, avoid using toothpastes that contain baking soda or are branded as whitening products.[12]
Gargle with a baking soda and water rinse. Combine 1 teaspoon (6 g) of baking soda and 1 cup (240 mL) of water in a glass, then stir the mixture until the baking soda is evenly distributed. Take a sip, gargle for about 30 seconds, then spit out the mixture. Repeat the steps until you’ve finished the entire glass.[13]
  • The baking soda rinse won't erode your teeth, so it's safe to gargle with it daily.
  • Gargling with a baking soda rinse whitens your teeth indirectly. Baking soda neutralizes acids, so it helps fight dental erosion caused by acidic foods and beverages. It can also help fight bacteria that cause decay and promote good bacteria that create a protective layer on your teeth.[14]
